displaytitle: 16. From Black and China, a Genisara is Born
creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund

makers.displaymaker: Buenaventura José Guiol, active late 18th century, Mexico

texts.textentryhtml: By descent with at least four paintings from the original set of sixteen (Princeton University Art Museum accession numbers 2022-45, 2022-46, 2022-47, 2022-48) in the Minguela family in Spain since at least 1940; following death of José María Minguela Velasco after 1996, the five paintings were distributed among his children Francisco Alfredo, Juan Antonio, José María, and Ana María Minguela Arjona; the group was reassembled in 2018 by dealer Jaime Eguiguren, Buenos Aires; purchased by the Princeton University Art Museum, May 2022.

Conceived as multi-image sets by prominent and unidentified eighteenth-century artists in Mexico, casta paintings document the process of mestizaje (racial mixing) among Amerindians, Spaniards, and Africans. The story the works tell, reinforced by the inscriptions, is that the mixture of Spaniards and Indians gave back “pure” or white Spaniards, while the union of Spaniards and Indians with Africans led to racial degeneration. The inferior status of Africans and their descendants is conveyed through signs of violence, poverty, and the use of zoological and other derogatory labels. This scene shows the couple viciously quarreling inside a kitchen in disarray while their distressed child attempts to stop them. These genealogical exercises are fictional and originate from social fears and the desire of colonists to uphold their power. Casta paintings shed light on the historical underpinning of race and how it continues to shape the allocation of privileges in contemporary society.

Ilona Katzew, Author of Casta Painting: Images of Race in Eighteenth-Century Mexico

exhibitions.citation: Object Lessons in American Art: Selections from the Princeton University Art Museum Saturday, February 4, 2023 - Sunday, January 7, 2024
